abstract.p: A well-known Maxwell’s model for evaluation of effective thermal conductivity has been modified incorporating a correction factor s. It is an important quantity, which influences the effective thermal conductivity of composite materials together with other parameters like volume fraction and thermal conductivities of the constituents. Parameter estimation technique is used to determine the value of s. Optimized value of s is used in the modified Maxwell’s model to estimate effective thermal conductivity of composite materials. The effective thermal conductivity of composite materials using an artificial neural network approach has also been calculated. Materials of different sizes of filler particles/matrix have been considered for calculation of the effective thermal conductivity. Results obtained using modified Maxwell’s model and artificial neural network technique have been compared with the experimental results available in the literature which shows a good fit.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Particle-filled polymer composites have become important because of their wide applications in science and engineering for technological developments. Incorporating inorganic fillers into a matrix enhances various physical properties of the materials such as mechanical strength, elastic modulus and heat-transfer coefficient.1,2 In general, the mechanical properties of particulate-filled polymer composites depend strongly on size, shape and distribution of filler particles in the polymer matrix.3

Thermal conductivity plays an important role in characterization of materials. Recent applications of polymers as heat sinks in electronic packaging, insulating envelope in solar ponds, nonconventional refrigerators and air conditioners in high-temperature furnaces, in explosive industry, in nuclear reactors and in missile technology requires new composites with relatively higher thermal conductivity. Improved thermal conductivity in polymers may be achieved either by molecular orientation or by the addition of conductive fillers. The addition of thermally conductive particles or short fibers to the polymers seems to be a good method to obtain conductive polymers. Such filled polymers with higher thermal conductivity than unfilled ones are becoming a more important area of study because of their wide range of applications.

Theoretical models for the prediction of the thermal conductivity of filled composites attempt to account for variations in the size, shape, intrinsic thermal conductivity and state of dispersion of the fillers.4–9 Even, when the intrinsic thermal conductivity is known, the wide variation in filler geometry, orientation and dispersion make it difficult to compare composites filled with different compounds. As a result, the experimental and predictive thermal conductivity data are often not in agreement. Therefore, it is very important to understand the effect of particle size and shape in composite materials. Maxwell10 calculated the effective thermal conductivity (ETC) of a random distribution of spheres in a continuous medium, which worked well for low-filler concentrations. Bruggeman11 derived another model for the ETC, under different assumptions for permeability and field strength. Hamilton and Crosser12 extended Maxwell’s model to include the empirical factor n to account for the shape of the particles (n = 3 for spheres and n = 6 for the cylinders). Cheng and Vachon13 and Agari et al.14 proposed various theoretical models for describing the heat transfer mechanism in polymer composites. Zhou et al.,15 Tekce et al.16 and Boudenne et al.17 studied the effect on the ETCs of various polymer composites considering various shapes and sizes of filler particles.

Parameter estimation technique is basically the process of model fitting, which provides tools for the efficient use of data, for aiding in mathematical modeling of phenomenon and estimation of constants appearing in the model. It is usually formulated as optimization one. The theoretically derived model includes parameters that describe physical properties of the observed system (e.g. ETC, porosity, diffusion coefficient, cation exchange capacity and others). Fitting a correct model produces estimated parameters that describe these physical properties with certain accuracy.

Along with the modification in the Maxwell’s model using size distribution law, in this paper, an artificial neural network (ANN) technique is also used for the calculation of ETC of composite materials. ANN technique is a computational model that is inspired by the structural/functional aspects of biological neural networks. In most cases, an ANN is an adaptive system that changes its structure based on external or internal information that flows through the network during the learning phase. Modern neural networks are non-linear statistical data-modeling tools. They are usually used to model complex relationships between inputs and outputs or to find patterns in data. The details of the used theoretical formulation as input to the simulated ANN are given elsewhere.18

ANNs are a form of artificial intelligence that attempts to mimic the behavior of human brain and the nervous system. The basic architecture consists of three types of neuron layers: input, hidden and output layers. ANNs have been of interest for many researchers and they applied it to many fields of modeling and prediction of many engineering systems, mathematics, physics, medicine, economics, meteorology, geotechnical and thermal engineering. It has become increasingly popular during the last decade. The main advantages of ANN in comparison with the classical methods are its high speed, simplicity and large capacity, which reduce engineering effort. In the last few years, many researchers18–22 used ANN approach to predict thermo-physical coefficients in different areas. Recently, Singh et al.18 used ANN and adaptive neuro fuzzy inference system in the study of thermal conductivity of rocks through physico-mechanical properties. A neural network has to be configured such that the application of a set of inputs produces the desired set of outputs. ANN simulations for predicting the ETC of composite systems were done using MATLAB R2010bSP1.

sec.title: Theory
sec.p: Holotesu and Floriana23 developed a mathematical model using the hypothesis that the system is composed of two types of composite materials. One of the composite materials (A) is having filler particles of different sizes and of known volume fraction φ and other composite material (B) is composed of filler particles of same size and having another volume fraction φe known as equivalent volume fraction. Applying this hypothesis to Maxwell’s10 model and using a distribution function known as Rosin-Rammler23 distribution function, a resultant equation is evaluated for the ETC of a composite system.

If (Di) are the diameters distributed according to the distribution function of Rosin-Rammler,23 then the probability density function is given by: (1)f(x)=sλ(xλ)s-1exp(-(xλ)s) where x=D/D1, s is the fitting parameter, λ is the scale parameter.

If D is the diameter of a particle and D1 is the arithmetic mean diameter of filler particles for volume Ω , then (2)D1=∫0∞nDf(x)dx∫0∞nf(x)dx=nD1λΓ(1+1s)n where Γ is the Gamma function and Ω is the representative volume.
The total volume occupied by the particles and the actual volume fraction φ is given by: (3)Vp=4π3∫0xnD3f(x)dx=4πnD133∫03x3f(x)3dx (4)Vp=4πnD133[Γ(1+3s)Γ(1+1s)] (5)φ=VpΩ=4πD133V[Γ(1+3s)Γ(1+1s)]
The scale parameter has the following form: (6)λ=1Γ(1+1s)

The Sauter mean diameter of the particle D32 defines the ensemble of n particles of different diameters Di which has the same specific area as the ensemble formed by n identical particles of diameter D32.

The equivalent volume fraction for material B is given by: (7)D32=∫0∞D3f(x)dx∫0∞D2f(x)dx=D1Γ(1+3s)Γ(1+1s)Γ(1+2s) (8)φe=n4πD3233nV=4πD133V[Γ(1+3s)Γ(1+1s)Γ(1+2s)]3 and the relationship between the equivalent volume fraction φe and the volume fraction φ is given by: (9)φe=χφ where (10)χ=Γ2(1+3s)Γ3(1+2s) is a constant that depends only on s, which defines the size-distribution law.

Hence, the modified Maxwell’s relation for ETC for the composite system using the size distribution law is given by: (11)ke=kmkf+2km+2φe(kf-km)kf+2km-φe(kf-km) where ke , km and kf are the ETC of the composite system, polymer matrix and the filler.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
Table 1 shows the samples under consideration with corresponding filler particles. The values of thermal conductivities and sizes of fillers used are also given in the table. For evaluation of ETC, a well-known Maxwell’s model has been modified by incorporating a correction factor s, which defines the filler particle size distribution law. Table 1.
Thermal conductivity, size and value of correction factor s for various samples.
Polymer matrix/fillerThermal conductivity of polymer matrix/filler (W/m-K)Size (µm) of filler/matrixValue of correction factors
Polypropylene/(Cu) 0.25/387 15 µm and 23µm 1.8 and 1.7
Polypropylene/(Al) 0.25/237 8 µm and 44 µm 3.1 and 2.6
Polyimide/(AlN) 0.22/200 1.25 µm and 2 µm 3.6 and 2.8
Polystyrene/(AlN) 0.15/160 0.15 mm and 2 mm/10 µm 1.9 and 1.5
Polymethylsiloxane/(Si3N4) 0.2/80 2 µm and 15 µm 5 and 4

The size distribution model has been used to determine the ETC of various composite materials. Parameter estimation technique was used to determine the value of s. Optimized value of s was used in the modified Maxwell’s model to determine the ETC of the composite systems. ANN approach is also used to determine the ETC of composite systems. Although the model is empirical one, it allows very good agreement with the experimental results, even for relatively high volume fractions. It is clear from the error analysis that the deviation in the value of ETC is less than 20% for samples having volume fractions upto 40%.

Boudenne et al.17 and Weidenfeller et al.24 presented the experimental results for polypropylene reinforced with copper and polypropylene reinforced with aluminum particles. The Rosin-Rammler distribution function was determined for these samples which gives well matching with the experimental results. Then, using the obtained size distribution and the size distribution model, we calculated the ETC of the composite systems. ANN technique is also used for calculation of ETC for these samples, which gives better fitting with the experimental results. For polypropylene reinforced with copper particles, the theoretical results using the size distribution model and experimental data fitted well for s = 1.8 and s = 1.7. The mean diameters of the fillers in this case were 15 µm and 23 µm. For polypropylene mixed with aluminum particles having mean diameters 8 µm and 44 µm, the theoretical results using the size distribution model and experimental data fitted well for s = 3.1 and s = 2.6. Figures 1 and 2 show the comparison between the results obtained using the size distribution model, the reference experimental data, Hamilton Crosser model and ANN approach. Figure 1.
Variation of effective thermal conductivity with filler volume fraction for polypropylene mixed with copper particles. Figure 2.
Variation of effective thermal conductivity with filler volume fraction for polypropylene mixed with aluminum particles.

The experimental results for a composite system, i.e. polyimide mixed with aluminum nitride particles, were given by Yi and Wang25 and Xu et al.26 The results obtained were compared with experimental data, Hamilton Crosser’s model and ANN approach. The theoretical results using the size distribution model and experimental data fitted well for s = 3.6 and s = 2.8 for the sizes 1.25 µm and 2 µm. Figure 3 shows the comparison of the results between the size distribution model, the experimental data, Hamilton Crosser model and ANN technique. Figure 3.
Variation of effective thermal conductivity with filler volume fraction for polyimide mixed with aluminum nitride particles.

Zhou et al.15 reported the experimental results for polymethylsiloxane reinforced with silicon nitride particles. The mean diameters of the fillers in the sample were 2 µm and 15 µm. The values of correction factor s which gives the best fit with experimental results are s = 5 and s = 4. The comparison of the results between the size distribution model, experimental data, Hamilton Crosser model and ANN technique is shown in Figure 4. Figure 4.
Variation of effective thermal conductivity with filler volume fraction for polymethylsiloxane mixed with silicone nitride particles.

We have also applied the size distribution model to the sample in which variation in the size of matrix is done, keeping the size of filler particle constant. Two different sizes of matrix were considered i.e. 0.15 mm and 2 mm for filler particle of size 10 µm. Yu et al.27 presented the experimental results for the composite system i.e. polystyrene mixed with aluminum nitride. The results obtained were then compared with experimental data and other models. The theoretical results using the size distribution model and experimental data fitted well for s = 1.9 and s = 1.5. Figure 5 shows the comparison of the results between the size distribution model, experimental data, Hamilton Crosser model and ANN technique. Figure 5.
Variation of effective thermal conductivity with filler volume fraction for polystyrene mixed with aluminum nitride particles.

It can be seen from the Figures 1–5 that at lower concentrations, up to 10% volume, for all the types of fillers, they are scattered in the bulk matrix almost without any interaction, so the rapid increase in the ETC of the composites cannot be observed. But as the concentration value of filler/matrix exceeded, a rapid increase in the ETC of the composites can be seen for the samples. It is observed from Figure 6 that for a given volume fraction, say 0.3, the ETC is in increasing order as the thermal conductivity of filler increases for the samples. The ETC is greater for bigger size of the filler particles in the sample considered showing the dependence on the size of the filler. Figure 6.
Variation of effective thermal conductivity with size of filler for the samples shown in Table 1.

We can see from Table 1 that in all the samples discussed above, the thermal conductivity of all the matrices is nearly same, so the overall change in the ETC values of the composite system is due to the contribution of the thermal conductivity of filler particles. The increase in thermal conductivity with increasing particle size of filler/matrix might be attributed to greater stability of thermal conductive pathways for the larger particles. In the case where size of filler is varied, when the size of particle increases, the area of interface between the particles and matrix will decrease. Therefore, there may be less matrix layer around each particle at the same content of matrix compared with the smaller filler particles. When variation in the size of matrix is done, there may be less matrix layer around each particle at the same content of filler compared with the smaller matrix particles. So, the heat conductive pathways can be considered more stable for the larger particles because the thicker conductive pathways have less chance of being disrupted by contacting grains.15,27

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Usually, in the literature, the variation in thermal conductivity is presented as a function of the volume fraction; the information regarding the size being limited mostly to the mean diameters. The acceptance for an empirical model to be valid is based on the agreement between its results with experimental data. Knowledge of the size distribution law allows for obtaining theoretical results in accordance with experimental data for various sizes of filler particles/matrix. The size distribution model is used to determine the ETC of a composite material. Although the model is empirical one, it shows very good agreement with experimental results for relatively high volume fractions as shown in the Figures 1–5. Hence, the size distribution model gives a good fit of ETC of the composite with the literature value.
